Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Information Processing by Gene Regulatory Network Controlling Bacterial Sporulation

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The ability of an organism to change its phenotype in response to various environmental cues is of fundamental biological importance, but the detailed mechanisms are not fully understood even for the best studied systems. The soil bacterium Bacillus subtilis detects currently unidentified starvation cues and processes this information via its gene regulatory networks, resulting in formation of a spore. Using this simple unicellular organism as a model, the long-term goal of this research is to discover general principles underlying the information processing by gene regulatory networks. Specifically, this project will uncover how B. subtilis processes information under conditions of environmental uncertainty and makes appropriate cell-fate decisions at the systems level. The cornerstone of the approach is a combination of in vivo and in vitro experiments as well as deterministic (population-average) and stochastic (single-cell) mathematical models. The key to success is the construction of synthetic strains which perturb various processes in the networks and the comparison of their responses to one another and to those in the wild-type strain. The experimental results will be analyzed using integrative mathematical models. The interdisciplinary nature of this research will uncover how signal-response characteristics and cell-fate decisions of the network are affected by its architecture.

Broader Impacts:
As a model system, B. subtilis offers significant experimental advantages including powerful genetic tools, large collections of mutant strains, and a fully sequenced genome. Unraveling the mechanisms of information processing by the sporulation network is a key step towards understanding the molecular basis of cell-fate decision at the unicellular level. Thus, the innovative approaches in this project may be applicable for addressing similar problems in other organisms and can be used for teaching system-level concepts to students of various levels and backgrounds. In particular, the resulting collection of synthetic strains can be used for educational purposes in the undergraduate laboratory setting because their networks are easy to perturb by varying the inducer levels. As a result, students will gain an understanding of the relationship between network architecture and system level properties. In addition, mathematical models can be used as a cornerstone for systems biology curriculum. The project will also provide abundant interdisciplinary training opportunities for the participating students from various backgrounds working together on experimental and/or mathematical modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When the Gram-positive soil bacterium Bacillus subtilis is exposed to starvation conditions, the cell switches from medial to asymmetric division to produce a larger mother cell and a smaller forespore, and then executes a complex developmental program leading to the production of a mature spore. B. subtilis has been used as a model organism due to its relative simplicity, the ease of genetic manipulation, and knowledge of its entire genomic sequence.

Previous studies using conventional molecular genetics and biochemistry approaches have accumulated a great deal of information about individual genes involved in B. subtilis sporulation. However a comprehensive understanding of the interactions of genes or their products at the systems level is still lacking. In this project we have aimed to elucidate how B. subtilis processes information and makes the decision to form a dormant spore under starvation conditions. This decision is critical for bacterial cell survival and thus cells must integrate information from both internal and external sources

Using a combination of experimental work and computer simulations, we found that cells are able to sense the state of their chromosomal DNA replication, resulting in pulsatile activation of the master transcriptional regulator of sporulation. During replication of the circular chromosome, each pulse is generated by a transient imbalance in gene dosage between the origin- and terminus-proximal genes and therefore peaks after the completion of DNA replication. This mechanism ensures that the mother cell and forespore compartments each receive a single chromosome to properly execute the compartment-specific gene-expression programs.

Furthermore, we found mechanisms modulating the amplitude of each pulse depending on the growth rate of the cell. This enables bacteria to indirectly detect environmental conditions without the need for evaluating specific signals. Thus, our interdisciplinary study explains how slow-down of cell growth leads to pulsatile accumulation of the key transcriptional regulator for unicellular differentiation, as well as how downstream gene networks initiate the cell differentiation program when the amplitude of the pulse exceeds the threshold level.  We propose that this decision strategy could be employed in a wide range of microbial species under stress conditions.

Overall, our team created systematic and efficient methods to dissect the complicated genetic network and uncovered a previously unrecognized regulatory mechanism involved in bacterial cell differentiation. Similar strategy may be applicable to other differentiation programs, such as meiosis in yeast and even cancer cell differentiation.

Notably, the project provided abundant training opportunities for participated students. The cross-disciplinary approaches, including synthetic biology, single-cell microscopy, and mathematical modeling, are essential for addressing complex biological questions in the post-genomic era. Trainees involved in this project are becoming the new generation of life scientists for whom no traditional discipline boundaries exist. Furthermore, the experimental samples created in this project have, upon request, been distributed to researchers all over the world.
